concern: I am not sure if this is executive dysfunction or my severe anxiety or if they are reinforcing each other but here is my issue. I nearly failed my general chemistry class. I kept telling people that I tried my very best and I didn't know what happened but that is not the truth. I do know what happened. I got to a point where I just stopped doing the work because the idea of doing it made me so anxious. I would watch tv for hours and take naps knowing that I should be doing chemistry work but I couldn't because I felt so anxious. In anticipation of a midterm I would have really bad body aches and headaches as a manifestation of this anxiety. I tried writing down my thoughts and pushing through but it never worked long term. I would start reading the textbook and then stop after 10 minutes because I just couldn't do it anymore. It was like a mixture of anxiety and boredom that was making feel like it was unbearable to do. I have to do better this semester to save my gpa but I don't know how to push through these feelings especially since therapy is not accessible to me at the moment.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session! I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Please feel free to share whatever is on your mind, and we'll work through it together.
Thanks for being here. I’m just really struggling with getting my schoolwork done, especially with chemistry, and I’m worried about how it’s affecting everything.
That sounds really stressful. Can you tell me more about what's been making chemistry so difficult for you?
Yeah, it’s just overwhelming, like I can’t even start without feeling this huge weight on me. I know I need to do better, but something keeps holding me back every time I try.

It sounds like you're caught between wanting to improve your chemistry grades and feeling paralyzed by the stress of it all. Can you tell me more about what happens when you try to start your schoolwork, and how that makes you feel?
Yeah, it’s like as soon as I think about starting, my whole body just tenses up and I feel this dread. I end up avoiding it altogether, even though I know that’s making things worse.

It sounds like the anxiety you feel when thinking about starting your chemistry work is really powerful and prevents you from moving forward. Can you tell me more about what this dread feels like in your body and how it affects your ability to focus?

Yeah, it’s like this heavy, sinking feeling in my chest, and sometimes I even get headaches or just feel completely drained before I’ve even started. It makes it almost impossible to focus because all I can think about is how much I don’t want to deal with it.

That sounds like an incredibly difficult and draining experience, especially when you're already trying so hard to push through. It's understandable that you'd feel stuck in this cycle, but I'm curious—what do you think might happen if you could find a way to ease that anxiety just a little bit before starting your work?

Honestly, I’m not even sure what would happen if I could ease the anxiety a bit, like, I guess I might be able to at least open the book without feeling like I’m gonna implode. It’s just hard to imagine getting to that point when it feels so overwhelming right off the bat.

It's completely normal to feel overwhelmed when dealing with intense anxiety, and it's a huge step just to imagine what might happen if that anxiety lessened. Let's explore this idea further: what do you think might help you take that first small step toward opening the book without feeling like you're going to implode?

I don’t know, maybe if I could break it down into something super small, like just reading one page or even a paragraph without any pressure to do more. I guess having some kind of distraction or reward afterward might help too, but I’m not sure what would actually get me to start without that dread kicking in right away.

It's great that you're able to consider smaller steps and potential distractions or rewards, even if they feel uncertain. Breaking down the task into manageable parts, like reading just one page or paragraph, might help make the anxiety feel less overwhelming. What do you think might happen if you were able to take that small step and find a way to cope with the anxiety that follows?

I think if I could manage that small step, like just reading a page, I might feel a tiny bit of relief or even some momentum to keep going, though I’m not totally sure. It’s just that the anxiety usually creeps back in so fast, so I’m worried it’ll still feel like too much even after that first step.

It sounds like breaking down the task into smaller steps could help ease the anxiety, even if it feels uncertain. I wonder if setting a specific time limit for reading, like 5 minutes, or having a calming activity ready for after, could help build momentum without feeling overwhelmed. What do you think might work best for you?

I think setting a super short time limit, like 5 minutes, could maybe trick my brain into not freaking out so much since it’s not a huge commitment. I’m also kinda curious about having something calming to do after, like listening to music or something, but I’m still worried I’ll just bail before even starting.

It's great that you're thinking about ways to make this manageable. What if we combined the 5-minute time limit with a calming activity afterward, like listening to a favorite song or taking a short walk? How do you think that might help you feel more prepared to start, even if the anxiety tries to creep in?

I think pairing the 5-minute limit with something like listening to a favorite song could maybe make it feel less daunting, like there’s something to look forward to right after. I’m just not sure if that’ll be enough to get me to actually sit down and start, since the anxiety still feels so heavy before I even try.

It’s understandable that the anxiety feels heavy before you even start, and it’s great that you’re thinking about ways to make this feel more manageable. What if we added a tiny, almost effortless step right before sitting down to read, like simply opening the book or setting it on your lap? Sometimes these micro-steps can make the transition feel less jarring and help build momentum.

I like the idea of a micro-step like just opening the book, ‘cause it feels way less intimidating than diving straight into reading. I’m just worried I’ll still freeze up even with something that small, but I guess it’s worth a shot to see if it helps me ease into it.

It's great that you're open to trying these micro-steps to ease into reading, even with the worry about freezing up. What if we also identified a specific time of day when you might feel slightly more calm or have a bit more control over distractions, to pair with these strategies and give yourself an even better chance to start?

I think picking a specific time of day could help, like maybe right after breakfast when I’m a bit more awake but not too stressed yet. I’m just not sure if I’ll stick to it, but I’m willing to try and see if it makes a difference.

That's a good starting point! How about setting a gentle reminder for yourself at that time, like a sticky note or a phone alert, to help signal to your brain that it's the agreed-upon moment to try the plan?

That sounds like a solid idea—having a reminder like a sticky note or phone alert could keep me from just forgetting or pushing it off. I’ll set something up for right after breakfast and see if it helps me get started with that micro-step of opening the book.

That’s a solid plan! Starting with a micro-step like opening the book and setting a gentle reminder for right after breakfast can help you ease into studying without feeling overwhelmed. It’s okay to feel unsure about sticking to it, but you’ve already taken a big step by creating a manageable approach. Remember, you’re not aiming for perfection—just progress. When you do sit down to study, try to focus on the process rather than the outcome, and celebrate small victories along the way. And don’t forget to pair your study time with something calming afterward, like a short walk or a cup of tea, to help you unwind. You’ve got this, and I’m here to support you every step of the way!

Thanks for the encouragement and the reminder to focus on progress over perfection—that really helps take some of the pressure off. I’ll definitely try pairing the study time with something relaxing afterward, and I’m glad to know I’ve got your support.
